  • attractive; good-looking; stylish; cool; smooth; neat; with-it; groovy

column1: ボブは、アメリカの大学の学生だ。
column2:
Bob is student of college of America.
- The order of modification is backwards so Bob is a student of a college that is American. 「学生の大学のアメリカ」 means “America of college of student” which is probably an error and makes little sense. (America of student’s college?)
- 119 Basic Grammar - Noun-related Particles: The 「の」 particle
column3: 119 Basic Grammar - Noun-related Particles: The 「の」 particle

column1: そのシャツは誰の？／ボブのだ。
column2:
Whose shirt is that? / It is of Bob.
- The noun that is being modified can be omitted if the context clearly indicates what is being omitted. The following highlighted redundant words can be omitted. Full: そのシャツは誰のシャツ？
- 120 Basic Grammar - Noun-related Particles: The 「の」 particle
column3: 120 Basic Grammar - Noun-related Particles: The 「の」 particle
column4: taekim/1581266292521-そのシャツは誰のボブのだ.mp3

column1: 白いのは、かわいい。
column2:
Thing that is white is cute.
- Same as 白い物は、かわいい。
- The 「の」 particle in this usage essentially replaces the noun and takes over the role as a noun itself. We can essentially treat adjectives and verbs just like nouns by adding the 「の」 particle to it. The particle then becomes a generic noun, which we can treat just like a regular noun.
- 121 Basic Grammar - Noun-related Particles: The 「の」 particle

- Summary: A sentence ending which indicates that the speaker is explaining or asking for an explanation about some information shared with the hearer, or is talking about something emotively, as if it were of common interest to the speaker and the hearer.
- Equivalent: The explanation is that ~; The reason is that ~; The fact is that ~; It is that ~
- This sounds very soft and feminine. In fact, adult males will almost always add a declarative 「だ」 unless they want to sound cute for some reason.

oFrms

:

  • (at sentence-end) indicates emotional emphasis
    (Female term or language)
  • (at sentence-end, rising tone) indicates question

column1: 今は忙しいのだ。
column2:
The thing is that (I'm) busy now.
- 129 Basic Grammar - Noun-related Particles: The 「の」 particle as explanation
- The 「の」 particle attached at the end of the last clause of a sentence can also convey an explanatory tone to your sentence. For example, if someone asked you if you have time, you might respond, “The thing is I’m kind of busy right now.” The abstract generic noun of “the thing is…” can also be expressed with the 「の」 particle. This type of sentence has an embedded meaning that explains the reason(s) for something else.
column3: 129 Basic Grammar - Noun-related Particles: The 「の」 particle as explanation

- Summary: A sentence ending which indicates that the speaker is explaining or asking for an explanation about some information shared with the hearer, or is talking about something emotively, as if it were of common interest to the speaker and the hearer.
- Equivalent: The explanation is that ~; The reason is that ~; The fact is that ~; It is that ~
- To express state-of-being, when the 「の」 particle is used to convey this explanatory tone, we need to add 「な」 to distinguish it from the 「の」 particle that simply means “of”.

- ジムなのだ。It is Jim (with explanatory tone).

column1:
自分の部屋

アリスは自分の部屋をきれいにした。
column2:
Alice did her own room toward clean.
- note that they turned 綺麗 into a suru verb
- GT: Alice has cleaned her room.
- could also be "Alice decided to clean her room", see にする in GG
- The literal translation kind of gives you a sense of why the target particle is used. There is some argument against calling this an adverb at all but it is convenient for us to do so because of the grouping of i-adjectives and na-adjectives. Thinking of it as an adverb, we can interpret the sentence to mean: “Alice did her room cleanly.” or less literally: “Alice cleaned her room.” （「きれい」 literally means “pretty” but if it helps, you can think of it as, “Alice prettied up her own room.”）

  • nominalizes verbs and adjectives

#そんな:

#の:
  • nominalizes verbs and adjectives

#有るある:

  • to have
    (usu. written as kana)

column1: 昨日何を食べたか忘れた。
column2:
Forgot what I ate yesterday.
- like "what I ate yesterday, forgot"
- Another use of the question marker is simply grammatical and has nothing to do with the politeness. A question marker attached to the end of a relative clause makes a mini-question inside a larger sentence. This allows the speaker to talk about the question.
- 024 Essential Grammar - The Question Marker - 「か」 used in subordinate clauses

column1: 彼は何を言ったかわからない。
column2:
Don't understand what he said.
- like "what did he say, don't understand"
- 025 Essential Grammar - The Question Marker - 「か」 used in subordinate clauses
#分かるわかる:
  • to understand; to comprehend; to grasp; to see; to get; to follow
    (Godan verb with ru ending; intransitive verb; usu. written as kana)
  • Other Forms　解るわかる、判るわかる、分るわかる

column1: 先生が学校に行ったか教えない？
column2:
Won't you inform me whether teacher went to school?
- like "did sensei go to school, would you like to inform me"
- 026 Essential Grammar - The Question Marker - 「か」 used in subordinate clauses
#教えるおしえる:
  • to teach; to instruct
    (Ichidan verb; Transitive verb)
  • to tell; to inform
  • Other Forms　訓えるおしえる

#か:
  • or; whether or not
    (after each alternative)
column3: 026 Essential Grammar - The Question Marker - 「か」 used in subordinate clauses
column4: taekim/1581266292542-先生が学校に行ったか教えない.mp3

column1: 先生が学校に行ったかどうか知らない。
column2:
Don't know whether or not teacher went to school.
- like "did the teacher go to school, whether or not, don't know"
- In sentences like example 3 where the question being considered has a yes/no answer, it is common (but not necessary) to attach 「どうか」. This is roughly equivalent to saying, “whether or not” in English. You can also include the alternative as well to mean the same thing.
- 027 Essential Grammar - The Question Marker - 「か」 used in subordinate clauses
#どうか:
  • somehow or other; one way or another
  • please
    (Adverb; Polite (teineigo))

#か:
  • or; whether or not
    (after each alternative)
column3: 027 Essential Grammar - The Question Marker - 「か」 used in subordinate clauses
column4: taekim/1581266292542-先生が学校に行ったかどうか知らない.mp3

column1:
行ったか行かなかったか

先生が学校に行ったか行かなかったか知らない。
column2:
Don't know whether teacher went to school or didn't.
- like "did sensei go to school or did not go, don't know"
- In sentences like example 3 where the question being considered has a yes/no answer, it is common (but not necessary) to attach 「どうか」. This is roughly equivalent to saying, “whether or not” in English. You can also include the alternative as well to mean the same thing.
- 028 Essential Grammar - The Question Marker - 「か」 used in subordinate clauses
#か:
  • or; whether or not
    (after each alternative)
column3: 028 Essential Grammar - The Question Marker - 「か」 used in subordinate clauses

column1:
どこ
どこか
どこも

#犯人はんにん:
  • offender; criminal; culprit
    (Noun)

#何処かどこか:
  • somewhere; anywhere; in some respects
    (Expression; Noun; Adverb; usu. written as kana)

#で:
  • at; in
    (Particle; indicates location of action; にて is the formal literary form)
  • Other Forms　にて

#何処もどこも:
  • everywhere; wherever
    (Conjunction; usu. written as kana)

column1:
どれ
どれか
どれも

この中からどれかを選ぶの。
column2:
(Explaining) You are to select a certain one from inside this [selection].
- どこか (where?)、誰か are unspecified (who?), therefore question words
- like "from inside this, select one of [the things]"
- 032 Essential Grammar - The Question Marker - Using question words
#中なか:
  • inside; in
    (Noun)

#から:
  • from (e.g. time, place, numerical quantity); since
    (Particle)

#どれか:
  • one of; any of
  • which one
    (Noun)

#何れどれ:
  • which (of three or more)
    (Pronoun; usu. written as kana)

#の:
  • (at sentence-end, falling tone) indicates a confident conclusion
    (often ん)
  • (at sentence-end) indicates emotional emphasis
    (Female term or language)
  • (at sentence-end, rising tone) indicates question

#何れもどれも:
  • any; all; every; both; either; none (with neg. verb)
    (Adverb; usu. written as kana)

    (Pronoun)

#誰もだれも:

  • and; then
    (Auxiliary; indicates continuing action; alternative form of 〜て used for some verb types)
  • Other Forms　にて

#て:
  • indicates continuing action
    (Auxiliary; で after certain verb forms)

column1: 彼女は、学生じゃなくて、先生だ。
column2:
She is not a student, she is a teacher.
- Summary: A て form of the negative ない, which indicates a cause/reason for a state or action. Equivalent: Do not do something and ~; is not ~ and ~; because ~ do not do something
- なくて is te form of ない
- 041 Essential Grammar - Compound Sentences - Expressing a sequence of states
#彼女かのじょ:
  • she; her
    (Pronoun)
  • girlfriend
    (Noun)

#て:

    (Auxiliary; で after certain verb forms)

    (Na-adjective)

column1: 映画を見たり、本を読んだり、昼寝したりする。
column2:
I do things like (among other things) watch movies, read books, and take naps.
- last suru determines tense, not shita
- This is the verb version of the 「や」 particle. You can make an example list of verbs among a possible larger list by conjugating each verb into the past tense and adding 「り」. At the end, you need to attach the verb 「する」.

column1: 今日、知りました。
column2:
I found out about it today. (I did the action of knowing today.)
-「知る」 means “to know”. English is weird in that “know” is supposed to be a verb but is actually describing a state of having knowledge. Japanese is more consistent and 「知る」 is just a regular action verb. In other words, I “knowed” (action) something and so now I know it (state). That’s why the English word “to know” is really a continuing state in Japanese, namely: 「知っている」.
- 080 Essential Grammar - Other uses of the te-form - Enduring state of being rather than enduring state of action
#知るしる:
  • to be aware of; to know; to be conscious of; to cognize; to cognise
    (Godan verb with ru ending; Transitive verb)
  • Other Forms　識るしる
column3: 080 Essential Grammar - Other uses of the te-form - Enduring state of being rather than enduring state of action
column4: taekim/1581266292552-今日知りました.mp3

column1: この歌を知っていますか？
column2:
Do (you) know this song?
- There are certain cases where an enduring state doesn’t translate into the progressive form. In fact, there is an ambiguity in whether one is in a state of doing an action versus being in a state that resulted from some action. This is usually decided by context and common practices. see http://www.guidetojapanese.org/learn/grammar/teform
- 081 Essential Grammar - Other uses of the te-form - Enduring state of being rather than enduring state of action
#歌うた:
  • song
    (Noun; 唄 is primarily used for shamisen songs)
  • Other Forms　唄うた、詩うた

This is usually decided by context and common practices. see http://www.guidetojapanese.org/learn/grammar/teform

column1: 鈴木さんはどこですか。／もう、家に帰っている。
column2:
Where is Suzuki-san? / He is already at home (went home and is there now).
- probably like てある (i.e. completed action) but with animate object (i.e. いる)
- It is reasonable to assume the actions 「行っている」 and 「来ている」 would mean, “going” and “coming” respectively. But unfortunately, this is not the case. The 「～ている」 form of motion verbs is more like a sequence of actions we saw in the last section. You completed the motion, and now you exist in that state. (Remember, 「いる」 is the verb of existence of animate objects.) It might help to think of it as two separate and successive actions: 「行って」、and then 「いる」.
- 084 Essential Grammar - Other uses of the te-form - Enduring state of being rather than enduring state of action

  • already; yet; by now; (not) anymore
  • Other Forms　もー

- It is reasonable to assume the actions 「行っている」 and 「来ている」 would mean, “going” and “coming” respectively. But unfortunately, this is not the case. The 「～ている」 form of motion verbs is more like a sequence of actions we saw in the last section. You completed the motion, and now you exist in that state. (Remember, 「いる」 is the verb of existence of animate objects.) It might help to think of it as two separate and successive actions: 「行って」、and then 「いる」.

column1: 準備はどうですか。準備は、もうしてあるよ。
column2:
How are the preparations? / The preparations are already done.
- Appropriately enough, just like there is an 「ある」 to go with 「いる」, there is a 「～てある」 form that also has a special meaning. By replacing 「いる」 with 「ある」, instead of a continuing action, it becomes a resultant state after the action has already taken place. Usually, this expression is used to explain that something is in a state of completion.
- analysis wrong. もうして = mousuru, NOT もうし
- してある = suru + aru, means "something already done", see https://japanese.stackexchange.com/a/41624

column1: 鉛筆を持っている？
column2:
Do (you) have a pencil?
- like "are you processing a pen"
- You can also use the motion verbs “to go” （行く）and “to come” （来る） with the te-form, to show that an action is oriented toward or from someplace. The most common and useful example of this is the verb 「持つ」 (to hold). While 「持っている」 means you are in a state of holding something (in possession of), when the 「いる」 is replaced with 「いく」 or 「くる」, it means you are taking or bringing something.

- 鉛筆を家に持ってくる？ - Are (you) bringing pencil to home?
- 鉛筆を家に持ってくる？ - Are (you) bringing pencil to home?

- ～ていく and ～てくる (usually written in kana, since they are such common suffixes) can express both physical movement (such as in 行い ってくる "go and come back") or a continued change in state.
- While 「持っている」 means you are in a state of holding something (in possession of), when the 「いる」 is replaced with 「いく」 or 「くる」, it means you are taking or bringing something.

column1: 今日は晴れて、富士山が見える。

- 見える is already the potential form of 見る. Jisho claims that there is a potential form of the potential form, but that's crap: https://japanese.stackexchange.com/a/43883 - wait... 見られる is the potential form of 見る, because it's an iru verb.
- THIS: There are two verbs 「見える」 and 「聞こえる」 that mean that something is visible and audible, respectively. When you want to say that you can see or hear something, you’ll want to use these verbs. If however, you wanted to say that you were given the opportunity to see or hear something, you would use the regular potential form.

- There are two verbs 「見える」 and 「聞こえる」 that mean that something is visible and audible, respectively. When you want to say that you can see or hear something, you’ll want to use these verbs. If however, you wanted to say that you were given the opportunity to see or hear something, you would use the regular potential form.

- However, for nouns, when you use the verb 「する」 with the 「に」 particle, it means that you are going to do things toward something. This changes the meaning of 「する」 to mean, “to decide on [X]”.

column1:
海外に行くことになった。
海外に行くことにした
column2:
- 海外に行くことになった。- It's been decided that I will go abroad. (lit: It became the event of going abroad.)
- 海外に行くことにした。 - I decided I will go abroad.
- ことになる, Summary: An event takes place as if spontaneously, irrespective of the speaker's volition. Equivalent: It will be decided that ~; come about ~; be arranged that ~; turn out that ~
- ことにする, Summary: A volitional decision to do something is made. Equivalent: Decide to

column1: 毎日、肉を食べるようになった。
column2:
It seems like I started eating meat everyday. (lit: It became the appearance of eating meat everyday.
- になった = became apparent
- GT: I started eating meat every day.
- ようになる - Some change takes place gradually. Equivalent: Reach the point where ~; come to ~; it has come to be that ~;
- You may be wondering how to use 「なる」 and 「する」 with verbs since there’s no way to directly modify a verb with another verb. The simple solution is to add a generic noun such as a generic event: こと （事） or an appearance/manner: よう （様）. These nouns don’t refer to anything specific and are used to describe something else. In this case, they allow us to describe verbs in the same manner as nouns. 
#様よう:
  • form; style; design
    (usu. after a noun)
  • thing (thought or spoken)
    (Noun)
  • appearing ...; looking ...
    (Noun - used as a suffix; Noun; usu. after the -masu stem of a verb; usu. written as kana)
column3: 125 Essential Grammar - Using する and なる with the に particle - Using 「なる」 and 「する」 with verbs

column1:
毎日、肉を食べるようにする。
毎日、肉を食べるようになった
column2:
- 毎日、肉を食べるようにする。- I will try to eat meat everyday. (lit: I will do toward the manner of eating meat everyday.)
- 毎日、肉を食べるようになった。- It seems like I started eating meat everyday. (lit: It became the appearance of eating meat everyday.

- ようにする - Summary: Someone causes some circumstantial or behavioural change to take place. Equivalent: Do ~ in such a way that ~; see to it that ~; make sure that ~; bring it about that ~
- ようになる - Some change takes place gradually. Equivalent: Reach the point where ~; come to ~; it has come to be that ~;

- However, for nouns, when you use the verb 「する」 with the 「に」 particle, it means that you are going to do things toward something. This changes the meaning of 「する」 to mean, “to decide on [X]”. 
- You may be wondering how to use 「なる」 and 「する」 with verbs since there’s no way to directly modify a verb with another verb. The simple solution is to add a generic noun such as a generic event: こと （事） or an appearance/manner: よう （様）. These nouns don’t refer to anything specific and are used to describe something else. In this case, they allow us to describe verbs in the same manner as nouns.
#為るする:
  • to decide on; to choose
    (as 〜にする; usu. written as kana)
  • to be just about to; to be just starting to; to try to; to attempt to
    (as 〜うとする,〜ようとする; usu. written as kana)

#様よう:
  • appearing ...; looking ...
    (Noun - used as a suffix; Noun; usu. after the -masu stem of a verb; usu. written as kana)
  • way to ...; method of ...ing
    (Noun - used as a suffix; Noun; usu. after the -masu stem of a verb)
  • thing (thought or spoken)
    (Noun)

- Contextual conditional. You can use this particle to express what will happen given a certain context. A context must be present to use it.
- ない is ある in negative
- 137 Essential Grammar - Conditionals - Contextual conditionals using 「なら（ば）」
#問題もんだい:
  • problem (e.g. societal, political); question; issue; subject (e.g. of research); case; matter
  • question (e.g. on a test); problem
    (Noun)

column1: 図書館はどこですか。／図書館なら、あそこです。
column2:
Where is the library? / If given that you're talking about the library, then it's over there.
- なら is conditional of だ
- 138 Essential Grammar - Conditionals - Contextual conditionals using 「なら（ば）」
#彼処あそこ:
  • there (place physically distant from both speaker and listener); over there; that place; yonder; you-know-where
    (Pronoun; usu. written as kana)
  • Other Forms　彼所あそこ、彼所あすこ、彼所かしこ、彼所あしこ、彼所あこ、アソコ

column1: 楽しければ、私も行く。
column2:
If it's fun, I'll go too.
- 141 Essential Grammar - Conditionals - General conditionals using 「ば」
- Conditional just expresses a regular “if” condition without any assumptions or embedded meanings.

If it's not fun, I'll also not go.

- 楽しくなければ、私も行かない。- If it's not fun, I'll also not go.

#無ければなければ:
  • if it does not exist; if it is not there; if it is not ...
    (Expression; usu. written as kana)

#ば:
  • if ... then; when
    (Particle)

column1:
もし
もしよかったら

もしよかったら、映画を観に行きますか？
column2:
If by any chance it's ok with you, go to watch movie?
- perhaps, if it's ok, ...
- もし is a supplement to add a sense of uncertainty on whether the condition is true.
- 152 Essential Grammar - Conditionals - How does 「もし」 fit into all of this?
#見るみる:
  • to see; to look; to watch; to view; to observe
    (Ichidan verb; Transitive verb)
  • Other Forms　観るみる、視るみる

  • if; in case; supposing
    (Adverb; usu. written as kana)

column4: taekim/1581266292561-もしよかったら映画を観に行きますか.mp3

column1: もし時間がないなら、明日でもいいよ。
column2:
If given that there's no time, tomorrow is fine as well. (Not certain whether there is no time)
- 「もし」 is really a supplement to add a sense of uncertainty on whether the condition is true. For instance, you might use it when you want to make an invitation and you don’t want to presume in like this sentence.
#若しもし:
  • if; in case; supposing
    (Adverb; usu. written as kana)

#でも:
  • but; however; though; nevertheless; still; yet; even so; also; as well
    (Conjunction)

#なら:
  • if; in case; if it is the case that; if it is true that
    (Auxiliary; hypothetical form of the copula だ, from なり and sometimes classed as a particle)
  • Other Forms　ならば

column1:
話せばどう？ (form?)
たま
たまに

たまにご両親と話せばどう？
column2:
How about talking with your parents once in a while?
- notice that 話す in conditional
- どう - Summary: An interrogative adverb which asks about the state of someone/something or the way of doing something. Equivalent: How; in what way
- You can make suggestions by using the 「ば」 or 「たら」 conditional and adding 「どう」. This literally means, “If you do [X], how is it?” In English, this would become, “How about doing [X]?”
- 189 Essential Grammar - Desire and Suggestions - Making Suggestions using the 「ば」 or 「たら」 conditional

  • Other Forms　適にたまに

    (Noun)

#ご両親ごりょうしん:

    (Noun; Honorific or respectful (sonkeigo))

column1:

column2:
- 「今日は授業がない」と先生から聞いたんだけど。 - It is that I heard from the teacher, "There is no class today."
- 先生から今日は授業がないと聞いたんだけど。 - I heard from the teacher that there is no class today.
- why no "however"? Used in the same manner as から and ので, but expresses contradiction.
- けど can be the an unfinished sentence like in English. e.g. It's okay, but ... [Sentence ends without continuation]. or use "though" when it fits.
#けど:
  • but; however; although
    (Conjunction; Particle)
  • Other Forms　けれど、けれども、けども、けんど

    (Conjunction)

- とする - we can use different verbs to do other things with the attempt. For instance, we can use the verb 「決める」 to say, “decide to attempt to do [X]”. Or 思う to say "thought to attempt to do X"
- GT: I thought I'd eat curry, but I didn't have time to eat it.

column1:
って
と言った

column2:
Tomoko said that she's going overseas next year.
- って can be an abbriviation for という (said ...), と言っている (says that ...), と聞いている (I hear that ...), とは / というのは (as for the term ...), は topic marker, と as conditional (if ... then)

- indirect quotes are like konjunktiv. "tomoko gehe nächstes jahr nach übersee"

  • I hear that ...
    (abbr. of と聞いている)
  • you said; he said; she said; they said
    (Particle; casual quoting particle)

- Like 「寒い」と言った. This idea of describing what a person is known or referred to as can also be extended to objects and places. We can essentially define and identify anything we want by using 「という」 in this manner.

column1:
さ (sentence end)

きっと
ようになる
ならいい

日本語は、たくさん勉強したけどな。まだ全然わからない。／大丈夫よ。きっとわかるようになるからさ。／ならいいけどな。
column2:
I studied Japanese a lot, right? But, I still don't get it at all. / No problem. You'll become able to understand for sure, you know? / If so, it would be good.
- GT: きっとわかるようになるからさ。／ならいいけどな。 = I'm sure you will understand. / I hope.
- You can use 「な」 in place of 「ね」 when it sounds too soft and reserved for what you want to say
- The 「な」 sentence-ending particle is often used with the question marker 「か」 to indicate that the speaker is considering something.
- さ - Basically a very casual form of 「よ」, is similar to the English “like” in that some people throw it in at the end of almost every single phrase.
- ようになる - Summary: Some change takes place gradually. Equivalent: Reach the point where ~; come to

column1:
食べたくなかった
食べさせられた

朝ご飯は食べたくなかったのに、食べさせられた。
column2:
Despite not wanting to eat breakfast, I was made to eat it.
- The causative-passive form is simply the combination of causative and passive conjugations to mean that the action of making someone do something was done to that person. This would effectively translate into, “[someone] is made to do [something]”. The important thing to remember is the order of conjugation. The verb is first conjugated to the causative and then passive, never the other way around. E.g. 食べる → 食べさせる → 食べさせられる
- 019 Special Expressions - Causative and Passive Verbs - Causative-Passive Forms

column1:
日本では、お酒を飲まされることが多い。
日本では、お酒を飲ませられることが多い。
column2:
- 日本では、お酒を飲まされることが多い。- In Japan, the event of being made to drink is numerous.
- 日本では、お酒を飲ませられることが多い。- In Japan, the event of being made to drink is numerous.
- 食べる → 食べさす
- 行く → 行か → 行かす
- 「する」 becomes 「さす」 and 「くる」 becomes 「こさす」.
- The causative-passive form is simply the combination of causative and passive conjugations to mean that the action of making someone do something was done to that person. This would effectively translate into, “[someone] is made to do [something]”. The important thing to remember is the order of conjugation. The verb is first conjugated to the causative and then passive, never the other way around. E.g. 食べる → 食べさせる → 食べさせられる

column1:
あいつに二時間も待たされた。
あいつに二時間も待たせられた。
column2:
- あいつに二時間も待たせられた。- I was made to wait 2 hours by that guy.
- あいつに二時間も待たされた。- I was made to wait 2 hours by that guy.

- 食べる → 食べさす
- 行く → 行か → 行かす
- 「する」 becomes 「さす」 and 「くる」 becomes 「こさす」.

- 待つ → 待たせる (causitive) → 待たれる (passive) → 待たせられる (passive causitive, られる because せる makes it an eる verb)
- BUT THIS IS SHORTEND Causative-Passive (す): 待たせる → 待たされる (with す it's not eる)

column1: 先生、お聞きしたいことがありますが。
column2:
Teacher, there's something I want to ask you.

- Grammar: お + stem + する. たい form of する.
- が is used in this way fairly often to act as a 'softener' by implying something like "there's something I want to ask, but I don't know if it's okay/you're busy/etc". It's just a way of making your question less impressing/more polite.
#が:
  • indicates sentence subject (occasionally object)
    (Particle)
column3: 045 Special Expressions - Honorific and Humble Forms - Humble Form
column4: taekim/1581266292580-先生お聞きしたいことがありますが.mp3

column1:
お待たせしました

すみません、お待たせしました。
column2:
Sorry, I made you wait (causative form).
- In causitive 待たせる it becomes an eる verb, and しました is polite past of する. Grammar point: お + stem + する
- 046 Special Expressions - Honorific and Humble Forms - Humble Form
column3: 046 Special Expressions - Honorific and Humble Forms - Humble Form
column4: taekim/1581266292580-すみませんお待たせしました.mp3

column1:
お預かりいたします

千円からお預かりいたします。
column2:
We'll be holding on [from?] your 1000 yen.
- お + 預かる + 致す
- just like noun + する. both are "to do" ...

- like "we will do take care of your 1000 yen"
- ５千円からお預かりいたします。３千円のおつりでございます。"Out of 5,000 yen (note). Here's your change, 3,000 yen."
- when the bill is 2,000 yen and the customer gives 5,000 yen, then the shop clerk will say "I'll 預かる 5,000 yen."
- So it's basically someone acknowledging the amount of money being given
- GT: We accept from 1,000 yen.
- You’ll hear something like example 4 when, for example, you need to get change after paying 1000 yen.
-「する」 has been converted to the humble 「致す」(いたす) form when it’s already in the お+stem+する humble form.
- 047 Special Expressions - Honorific and Humble Forms - Humble Form

    (Godan verb with ru ending; Transitive verb)

#致すいたす:
  • to do
    (Godan verb with su ending; Transitive verb; Humble (kenjougo); usu. written as kana)

#預かりあずかり:

    (Noun)

    (Noun)
  • Other Forms　預りあずかり

There is yet another very colloquial version of 「～てしまう」 and 「～でしまう」 where it is replaced by 「～ちまう」 and 「～じまう」 respectively. Unlike the cuter 「～ちゃう」 and 「～じゃう」 slang, this version conjures an image of rough and coarse middle-aged man.

- There is yet another very colloquial version of 「～てしまう」 and 「～でしまう」 where it is replaced by 「～ちまう」 and 「～じまう」 respectively. Unlike the cuter 「～ちゃう」 and 「～じゃう」 slang, this version conjures an image of rough and coarse middle-aged man.

  • unintentionally; subconsciously; by mistake; against one's better judgement (judgment)
    (Adverb)

column1: もう家に帰るんだろう。／そうよ。
column2:
You're going home already, right? / That's right.
- 「でしょう」 is used to express a level of some certainty and is close in meaning to 「多分」. Just like 「～です／～ます」, it must come at the end of a complete sentence. It does not have any other conjugations.
- It's the polite volitional form of だ. And だろうis the plain form.
- GT: I'm going home now. /that's right.

  • always; constantly
    (usu. written as kana)
  • Other Forms　許ばかり、許ばっかり、許ばっか

  • it seems; I think; I guess; I wonder
    (Expression)
  • right?; don't you agree?
  • Other Forms　でしょ

#遊ぶあそぶ:
  • to meet up (with friends); to hang out
    (Godan verb with bu ending; intransitive verb)
  • to play (games, sports); to enjoy oneself; to have a good time
    (Godan verb with bu ending; intransitive verb)

様な

column1: 時間が足りなさすぎて、何もできなかった。
column2:
Due to too much of a lack of time, I couldn't do anything.
- 足りない is adjective because 足る negated would be 足らない
- GT: I was too short on time and couldn't do anything.
- For negative verbs and adjectives: Replace the last 「い」 from 「ない」 with 「さ」 and then attach 「すぎる」
- 129 Special Expressions - Expressing amounts - Saying there's too much of something using 「すぎる」

  • to be sufficient; to be enough
    (Ichidan verb; intransitive verb)

#足るたる:
  • to be sufficient; to be enough
    (Godan verb with ru ending; intransitive verb)

#出来るできる:
  • to be able (in a position) to do; to be up to the task
    (Ichidan verb; intransitive verb; usu. written as kana)
  • Other Forms　出きるできる、出來るできる

column1: 韓国料理は食べれば食べるほど、おいしくなる。
column2:
About Korean food, the more you eat the tastier it becomes.
- When you use this with conditionals, you can express something that translates into English as, “The more you [verb], the more…” The grammar is always formed in the following sequence: [conditional of verb] followed immediately by [same verb+ ほど]
- The literal translation is, “About Korean food, if you eat, to the extent that you eat, it becomes tasty.” which essentially means the same thing. 
- 137 Special Expressions - Expressing amounts - Using 「ほど」 to express the extent of something
#料理りょうり:
  • cooking; cookery; cuisine
    (Noun; Suru verb)

#程ほど:
  • extent; degree; measure
    (Noun; usu. written as kana)
  • the more ... the more ...
    (oft. as 〜ば...ほど; usu. written as kana)
column3: 137 Special Expressions - Expressing amounts - Using 「ほど」 to express the extent of something

column1: もう売り切れみたい。

column1:
訳ない
訳がない

広子の家に行ったことある？／あるわけないでしょう。
column2:
Have you ever gone to Hiroko's house? / There's no way I would have ever gone to her house, right?
- Under the normal rules of grammar, we must have a particle for the noun 「わけ」 in order to use it with the verb but since this type of expression is used so often, the particle is often dropped to create just 「～わけない」.
- GT: Have you been to Hiroko's house? / There is no way.
#訳がないわけがない:
  • there is no way that ... (expresses speaker's belief that something is impossible)
    (Expression; usu. written as kana)
  • Other Forms　わけが無いわけがない、訳が無いわけがない

  • (there is) no reason
    (Expression; contraction of 訳が無い; usu. written as kana)
  • easy; simple
    (I-adjective; usu. written as kana)
  • Other Forms　訳ないわけない

  • right?; don't you agree?
  • Other Forms　でしょ

#有るある:

    (usu. written as kana)
  • Other Forms　在るある

column1:
とする
として
としても

朝ご飯を食べたとしても、もう昼だからお腹が空いたでしょう。
column2:
Even assuming that you ate breakfast, because it's already noon, you're probably hungry, right?
- As you can see, the verb 「する」 has been conjugated to the 「たら」 conditional form to consider what would happen if you assume a certain case. You can also change 「する」 to the te-form （して） and use it as a sequence of actions

    (Expression)

    (Expression; before a negative form)

column2:

column1: 早く帰るべき。
column2:
Should go home early.
- Grammatically, 「べく」 is really a conjunctive form of 「べき」, similar to what the te-form does to connect another phrase. While 「べき」 describes a strong suggestion, changing it to 「べく」 allows you to describe what one did in order to carry out that suggestion.
- 018 Advanced Topics - Things that should be a certain way - Using 「べく」 to describe what one tries to do

    (Auxiliary; suf. to verbs; usu. written as kana)

#べく:
  • must; should
    (Auxiliary; Suffix)

#早いはやい:
  • fast; quick; hasty; brisk
    (I-adjective; esp. 速い, 疾い, 捷い)
  • early (in the day, etc.); premature
    (esp. 早い)
  • Other Forms　速いはやい、疾いはやい、捷いはやい

天才
天才の私ですら
すら
さえ

この天才の私ですらわからなかった。
column2:
Even a genius such as myself couldn't solve it.
- GT: 天才の私ですら = Even I, a genius
- GT: Even I, this genius, didn't understand.
- 「（で）すら」 is a older variation of 「（で）さえ」 that is not as commonly used.
- In English, we might say, “not even close”. In Japanese, we can express this by attaching 「さえ」 to the object or verb that miserably failed to reach what one would consider to be a bare minimum requirement.
- 030 Advanced Topics - Expressing the minimum expectation - 「（で）すら」 - Same as 「（で）さえ」 but different?
#天才てんさい:

    (Noun)

#分かるわかる:
  • to understand; to comprehend; to grasp; to see; to get; to follow
    (Godan verb with ru ending; intransitive verb; usu. written as kana)
  • Other Forms　解るわかる、判るわかる、分るわかる

#さえ:
  • even; if only; if just; as long as; the only thing needed
    (Particle)

column1:
使いたがる

家に帰ったら、すぐパソコンを使いたがる。
column2:
[He] soon acts like wanting to use computer as soon as [he] gets home.
- Past would be 使った. So it's 使いたい.
- 「～がる」 grammar is used when you want to make an observation about how someone is feeling. This grammar can only be used with adjectives.
- This grammar is also used to observe very frankly on what you think someone other than yourself wants. This involves the adjective 「欲しい」 for things one wants or the 「～たい」 conjugation for actions one wants to do, which is essentially a verb conjugated to an i-adjective.

column1:
寒がり屋
辛い
辛い

column2:

- 「～がる」 grammar is used when you want to make an observation about how someone is feeling. This grammar can only be used with adjectives.
- 「～がる」 is also used with 「屋」 to indicate a type of person that often feels a certain way such as 「恥ずかしがり屋」 (one who easily feels or acts embarrassed)、 「寒がり屋」 (one who easily feels cold)、or 「暑がり屋」 (one who easily feels hot).
- 042 Advanced Topics - Showing signs of something - Showing outward signs of an emotion using 「～がる」

  • to show signs of being; to feel; to think

    (I-adjective)
  • painful; bitter; difficult; tough

  • painful; bitter; heart-breaking; difficult (emotionally)
    (I-adjective; usu. written as kana)

column1:
爆発せんばかり
膨らむ

ボールは爆発せんばかりに、膨らんでいた。
column2:
The ball was expanding as if it was going to explode.
- For present, non-negative: Conjugate the verb to the 「ん」 negative form and attach 「ばかり」 Example: 言う → 言わない → 言わん → 言わんばかり
- Shortened version of "stem + ない" - Exceptional conjugations: する → せん、くる → こん

- Use 「ばかり」 to indicate that one seems to want to do something. This grammar is completely different from the 「ばかり」 used to express amounts and the 「ばかり」 used to express the proximity of an action.
- 043 Advanced Topics - Showing signs of something - Using 「ばかり」 to act as if one might do something
#膨らむふくらむ:
  • to expand; to swell (out); to get big; to become inflated
    (Godan verb with mu ending; intransitive verb)
  • Other Forms　脹らむふくらむ

#爆発ばくはつ:
  • explosion; detonation; eruption
    (Noun; Suru verb)

#許りばかり:
  • as if to; (as though) about to
    (after an attributive form or auxiliary verb ぬ(ん), also often …とばかり(に); usu. written as kana)
  • only; merely; nothing but; no more than
    (Particle; usu. written as kana)
  • Other Forms　許ばかり、許ばっかり、許ばっか
column3: 043 Advanced Topics - Showing signs of something - Using 「ばかり」 to act as if one might do something

column1:
これ以上
これ以上壊れたら
ざるを得ない

このテレビがこれ以上壊れたら、新しいのを買わざるを得ないな。
column2:
If this TV breaks even more, there's no choice but to buy a new one.
- This grammar is used when there’s something that just can’t be helped and must be done. It uses the negative of the verb 「得る」 or “obtain”, to roughly mean that “one cannot obtain not doing of an action”. This means that you can’t not do something even if you wanted to.

    (Expression; I-adjective; after the -nai stem of a verb)

#これ以上これいじょう:
  • any more; any further; any better; any longer
    (Expression; usu. with neg. sentence)

I tolerated it all this time but in this situation, I can't not go to the dentist.
- GT: してきた = Have done
- GT: ずっと我慢してきた = I've been patient

- This grammar is used when there’s something that just can’t be helped and must be done. It uses the negative of the verb 「得る」 or “obtain”, to roughly mean that “one cannot obtain not doing of an action”. This means that you can’t not do something even if you wanted to.
- 050 Advanced Topics - Formal expressions of non-feasibility - Expressing the inability to not do using 「～ざるを得ない」
#ざるを得ないざるをえない:
  • cannot help (doing); have no choice but to; am compelled to; am obliged to; it is incumbent upon (me) to
    (Expression; I-adjective; after the -nai stem of a verb)

column1:
~せざるを得ない

上司の話を聞くと、どうしても海外に出張をせざるを得ないようです。
column2:
Hearing the story from the boss, it seems like I can't not go on a business trip overseas no matter what.
- This grammar is used when there’s something that just can’t be helped and must be done. It uses the negative of the verb 「得る」 or “obtain”, to roughly mean that “one cannot obtain not doing of an action”. This means that you can’t not do something even if you wanted to.
- This grammar uses an archaic negative form of verbs that ends in 「～ざる」. It is really not used in modern Japanese with the exception of this grammar and some expressions such as 「意図せざる」. The rules for conjugation are the same as the negative verbs, except this grammar attaches 「ざる」 instead. To reiterate, all you have to do is conjugate the verb to the negative form and then replace the 「ない」 with 「ざる」. The two exception verbs are 「する」 which becomes 「せざる」 and 「くる」 which becomes 「こざる」. Finally, all that’s left to be done is to attach 「を得ない」 to the verb.
#ざるを得ないざるをえない:
  • cannot help (doing); have no choice but to; am compelled to; am obliged to; it is incumbent upon (me) to
    (Expression; I-adjective; after the -nai stem of a verb)

#如何してもどうしても:
  • by all means; at any cost; no matter what; at any rate; surely
    (Expression; Adverb; usu. written as kana)
  • whether (one is) willing or not; willingly or unwillingly; willy-nilly
    (Expression; Adverb; usu. written as kana)
column3: 051 Advanced Topics - Formal expressions of non-feasibility - Expressing the inability to not do using 「～ざるを得ない」
column4: taekim/1581266292605-上司の話を聞くとどうしても海外に出張をせざるを得ないようです.mp3

column1:

If the paperwork should be late due to uncontrollable circumstance, please make sure to contact us.
- GT: If the procedure is delayed due to unavoidable reasons, please be sure to contact us.
- Similar to ～ざるを得ない, to say that one cannot obtain the stopping of something. If you have already learned 「仕方がない」 or 「しょうがない」, this grammar means pretty much the same thing. The difference lies in whether you want to say, “Looks like we’re stuck” vs “Due to circumstances beyond our control…”
- 052 Advanced Topics - Formal expressions of non-feasibility - Expressing the inability to stop doing something using 「やむを得ない」
#やむを得ないやむをえない:

    (Expression; I-adjective)
  • Other Forms　止むを得ないやむをえない、已むを得ないやむをえない

#事由じゆう:
  • reason; cause
    (Noun)

#に因りにより:
  • according to; by (means of); due to; because of
    (Expression; usu. written as kana)
  • Other Forms　に依りにより

#手続きてつづき:
  • procedure; process; proceedings; formalities
    (Noun; Suru verb)
  • Other Forms　手続てつづき

column1: テレビを見ながら、寝ちゃダメよ！
column2:
Don't watch TV while sleeping!
- テレビを見つつ、寝ちゃダメよ！would sound unnatural.
- 「つつ」 is a verb modifier that can be attached to the stem of verbs to express an ongoing occurrence. two ways to use this grammar. The first is almost identical to the 「～ながら」 grammar. You can use 「つつ」 to describe an action that is taking place while another action is ongoing. Second, 「～ながら」 is used to describe an auxiliary action that takes place while the main action is going on.<br>
- 059 Advanced Topics - Tendencies - Describing an ongoing occurrence using 「～つつ」
#つつ:
  • while
    (Particle; after the -masu stem of a verb)
  • even though; despite

column1:
がてら
散歩がてら

column2:
While taking a stroll, I also used that time to buy cigarettes.
- This rather formal and seldom-used grammar is used to indicate that two actions were done at the same time. The nuance is a bit difference from 「ながら」 in that some or all of the time spent on doing one action was also used to do another action as an aside. Remember, 「ながら」 is used to describe two exactly concurrent actions.

  • on the same occasion; at the same time; coincidentally; along with; partly (to do, for)

博物館
見がてら

column2:
While seeing the museum, I plan to also use that time to buy souvenirs.
- This rather formal and seldom-used grammar is used to indicate that two actions were done at the same time. The nuance is a bit difference from 「ながら」 in that some or all of the time spent on doing one action was also used to do another action as an aside. Remember, 「ながら」 is used to describe two exactly concurrent actions.
- 097 Advanced Topics - Others - Using 「～がてら」 to do two things at one time
- GT: I will buy souvenirs while looking at the museum.
#がてら:
  • on the same occasion; at the same time; coincidentally; along with; partly (to do, for)
    (Particle)
column3: 097 Advanced Topics - Others - Using 「～がてら」 to do two things at one time
column4: taekim/1581266292611-博物館を見がてらにお土産を買うつもりです.mp3

column1:
あげく
説明をしたあげく
納得

事情を2時間かけて説明をしたあげく、納得してもらえなかった。
column2:
[After a great deal of] explaining the circumstances for 2 hours, [in the end], couldn't receive understanding.
- GT: After explaining the situation over two hours, I was not convinced.
- 「あげく」 is a grammar used to describe a result, usually negative, that came about after a great deal of effort.
- 098 Advanced Topics - Others - Using 「～あげく（挙句）」 to describe a bad result
#挙句あげく:
  • in the end (after a long process); finally; after all; at last
    (Adverbial noun; Temporal noun; esp. 〜したあげく; usu. written as kana)
  • Other Forms　挙げ句あげく、揚げ句あげく、揚句あげく

#事情じじょう:
  • circumstances; conditions; situation; reasons; state of affairs
    (Noun)

#納得なっとく:
  • consent; assent; agreement
    (Noun; Suru verb)
  • understanding; comprehension; grasp
    (Noun; Suru verb)
column3: 098 Advanced Topics - Others - Using 「～あげく（挙句）」 to describe a bad result
column4: taekim/1581266292611-事情を2時間かけて説明をしたあげく納得してもらえなかった.mp3

column1:
あげく
相談のあげく
退学

先生と相談のあげく、退学することにした。
column2:
[After much] consulting with teacher, [in the end], decided on dropping out of school.
- 「あげく」 is a grammar used to describe a result, usually negative, that came about after a great deal of effort.
- 099 Advanced Topics - Others - Using 「～あげく（挙句）」 to describe a bad result
#挙句あげく:
  • in the end (after a long process); finally; after all; at last
    (Adverbial noun; Temporal noun; esp. 〜したあげく; usu. written as kana)
  • Other Forms　挙げ句あげく、揚げ句あげく、揚句あげく

#あげくの果てあげくのはて:
  • finally; in the end; on top of all that
    (Expression; Adverb; Noun; usu. as ～に)
  • Other Forms　挙げ句の果てあげくのはて、挙句の果てあげくのはて、揚げ句の果てあげくのはて、揚句の果てあげくのはて

#退学たいがく:
  • dropping out of school; withdrawing from school
    (Noun; Suru verb)
column3: 099 Advanced Topics - Others - Using 「～あげく（挙句）」 to describe a bad result
